Zinc/magnesium–sodium/lithium heterobimetallic triphenolates: Synthesis, characterization, and application as catalysts in the ring-opening polymerization of l-lactide and CO2/epoxide coupling Yangyang Sun a Lei Wang b ⁎ Dawei Yu a Ning Tang a Jincai Wu a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Nonferrous Metals Chemistry and Resources Utilization of Gansu Province and State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China Key Laboratory of Nonferrous Metals Chemistry and Resources Utilization of Gansu Province and State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University Lanzhou 730000 China b College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Key Laboratory of Eco-Environment-Related Polymer Materials, Ministry of Education of China, Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials of Gansu Province, Lanzhou 730070, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Key Laboratory of Eco-Environment-Related Polymer Materials, Ministry of Education of China, Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials of Gansu Province Lanzhou 730070 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 931 8912552; fax: +86 931 8912582. Graphical abstract A series of heterobimetallic complexes catalyzed the ring-opening polymerization of l-LA in a controlled fashion. What is more, both of these two complexes could catalyze l-LA with high conversion even in the air. The application catalyzed by 1 and 2 in the presence of n-Bu4NX (X =Cl, Br) were also investigated under mild conditions. A series of heterobimetallic complexes supported by a bulky trisphenol ligand were synthesized and characterized. Treatment of 2,6-bis(3,5-bis-t-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)-4-t-butyl phenol with 1 equivalent sodium/ n BuLi and 1 equiv. Zn(Et)2 in THF solution afforded complex 1 or 2; metal complexes 3 and 4 were obtained in quantitative yields by alternating Zn(Et)2 to Mg( n Bu)2. The X-ray structures of 2 and 3 indicated that four metal atoms in the complexes are nearly collinear. Catalysis employing complexes 1–3 for l-lactide (l-LA) was systematically studied, and experimental results showed that 1 and 2 can catalyze the ring-opening polymerization of l-LA in a controlled fashion; what is more, both of these two complexes could catalyze l-LA with high conversion even in an air atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 also can effectively catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with cyclohexene oxide using n-Bu4NBr/n-Bu4NCl as co-catalysts. Keywords Polylactide Cyclohexene oxide Ring-opening polymerization Catalyst Heterobimetallic complex 1 Introduction In the past several decades, aliphatic polyesters have drawn wide attention due to their biocompatible, biodegradable, and permeable properties, which are important in biomedical and pharmaceutical applications [1]. Specifically, polylactide (PLA), which can be derived from renewable resources for its starting materials originating from glucose fermentation, has found wide applicability, including medical, agricultural, and packaging applications [2]. A promising method to prepare PLA is the ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of lactide for the prominent features of controlled molecular weight and low polydispersity (PDI) [3]. Many metal complexes including aluminum [4], zinc [5], magnesium [6], alkali metal [7], tin [8], lanthanide [9], and other metals [10] have been reported as excellent initiators/catalysts with well-characterized results achieved. Nevertheless, most of these well-defined metal initiators require rigorously anhydrous conditions due to their air- and moisture-sensitivity. Therefore, there is an exigent need to develop a practical means for the well-controlled ROP of lactide in laboratories and industry without access to inert-atmosphere facilities or rigorously dried solvents and to reduce the cost. Some robust metal catalysts such as zirconium Schiff base alkoxide [11], zinc Schiff base complex [12], and iron alkoxides [13] were introduced in the catalytic system to initiate/catalyze ROP of cyclic esters in the presence of air, water or acid and showed a good performance. A diphenol-based heterobimetallic complex [(TBBP)2Zn][(Na)2(THF)4] (TBBP-H2 =3, 3′, 5, 5′-tetra-tert-butyl-2,2′-biphenol) reported by our group [14] demonstrated a controlled fashion for the ROP of lactide even in the presence of water. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an attractive chemical feedstock: it is highly abundant, renewable, inexpensive, and of low toxicity [15]. Owing to these advantages, the utilization of CO2 in the coupling reaction with epoxides to afford polycarbonates and/or cyclic carbonates has received much attention [16]. Accordingly, a wide variety of metal-based catalytic systems (e.g. Al [17], Mg [18], Zn [19], Co [16e,20], Cr [21]) have been developed for this transformation. Although numerous metal catalysts have been employed to efficiently catalyze CO2/epoxide coupling, heterobimetallic complexes applied in the coupling reaction are rarely reported to the best of our knowledge [22]. Herein, we describe the synthesis and characterization of a series of novel heterobimetallic complexes 1–4, supported by a bulky trisphenol ligand. X-ray structural studies of complexes 2 and 3 are presented as well. The experimental results of the polymerization of l-lactide under an air atmosphere suggest that two of these metal complexes are robust and excellent catalysts. Additionally, the application of 1 and 2 as catalysts toward cycloaddition of CO2 with cyclohexene oxide to obtain cyclohexene carbonate is also presented in this work (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 General considerations All manipulations were carried out under a dry nitrogen atmosphere. Solvents, l-lactide, and benzyl alcohol (BnOH) were purified before using and stored in solvent reservoirs which contained 4Å molecular sieves and were purged with nitrogen. n BuLi (2.4M in hexane), Zn(Et)2 (1.0M in hexane), and Mg(n-Bu)2 (1.0M in heptane) were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. Commercial chemicals were purchased and used without further purification. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using spectrometers of the Varian Mercury Plus family with chemical shifts given in parts per million from the peak of internal TMS. Microanalyses were performed by using a Heraeus CHN-O-RAPID instrument. The GPC measurements were performed on a Hitachi L-700 system equipped with a differential Bischoff 8120 RI detector by using THF (HPLC grade) as an eluent running at 1mL/min. Molecular weights and molecular weight distributions were calculated using polystyrene as standard. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of [(L)2(Zn)2][(Na)2(THF)4] (1) A solution of 2, 6-bis(3, 5-di-t-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)-4-t-butyl phenol (H 3 –L) (0.594g, 1.0mmol) and sodium (0.025g, 1.1mmol) was stirred in THF (20mL) overnight at 50°C under a N2 atmosphere. Zn(Et)2 (1.1mL, 1.1mmol, 1.0M hexane) was then added slowly. The solution was stirred for 6h at room temperature and a white precipitate was achieved. The resulting precipitate was collected by filtration. The residue was washed with hexane twice and dried under vacuum to give white solids. Attempts to isolate the suitable single crystals of 1 were unsuccessful. (Found) for C96H142O10Mg2Na2: C 74.61 (74.35), H 8.90 (9.23) %. 2.3 Polymerization of l-LA catalyzed by complexes 1–3 A typical polymerization procedure is exemplified by the synthesis of PLLA-150 (the number 150 indicates the designed [monomer]0/[complex]0 ratio) at 110°C (Table 1 , entry 1). The polymerization conversion was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. l-Lactide (0.432g, 3.0mmol) was added to a solution of complex 1 (0.032g, 0.02mmol) in toluene (10mL). In the case where an initiator was used, the solution of benzyl alcohol (0.1M in toluene) from a stock solution in toluene was injected sequentially to the solution. After the solution was stirred at 110°C for 36h, the reaction was quenched with the addition of water (0.5mL). The solvent was then removed under vacuum, and a white crystalline solid was obtained by recrystallization with the mixed solvents of hexane/CH2Cl2 and dried under vacuum. 2.4 Cycloaddition of CO2 and CHO catalyzed by complexes 1–2 in the presence of quaternary ammonium salts (n-Bu4NX) A representative procedure for the cycloaddition of cyclohexene oxide with CO2 (Table 3, entry1) was exemplified. Catalyst 1 (0.032g, 0.02mmol) and (co-catalyst) n-Bu4NCl (0.556g, 0.2mmol) were dissolved in 2mL of neat cyclohexene oxide to the 50mL autoclave with magnetic stirrer under an air atmosphere. CO2 was then charged into the reactor until the pressure of 20bar was reached, and the mixture started to be stirred. The reaction was performed at 80°C for 16h. Then the reactor was placed into ice water and excess CO2 was released. The CHO conversion (56%) was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopic studies in CDCl3, based on spectral characteristics of cyclohexene carbonate: mutiplets: δ =3.96ppm (trans-CHC) or 4.63ppm (cis-CHC) [23]. The mixture was then quenched by the addition of 1M HCl solution (1.0mL), the carbonate was extracted with hexane (3mL×50mL) and the organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The solvent was removed under vacuum and white oil was obtained. 2.5 X-ray crystallographic studies Suitable crystals of 1 and 3 were sealed in thin-walled glass capillaries under a nitrogen atmosphere and were mounted on a Bruker AXS SMART 1000 diffractometer. Intensity data were collected in 1350 frames with increasing (width of 0.3° per frame). The absorption correction was based on the symmetry-equivalent reflections using the program SADABS. The space group determination was based on a check of the Laue symmetry and systematic absence and was confirmed using the structure solution. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs [24]. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of complexes 1–4 The ligand of 2,6-bis(3,5-bis-t-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)-4-t-butyl phenol (H 3 –L) was synthesized according to the published procedure [25]. The heterobimetallic complexes 1 and 2 were prepared by treatment of H 3 –L with 1.1 equiv. sodium (for 1) or n BuLi (for 2) and 1.1 equiv. Zn(Et)2 in THF solution, affording a white target product in almost quantitative yields (Scheme 2 ). A similar procedure in which Zn(Et)2 was replaced by Mg( n Bu)2 gave 3 and 4 in 67 and 58% yields, respectively. Compared with 1 and 4, complexes 2 and 3 could be more easily dissolved in THF and toluene solvents. In addition, it was found that complex 2 is much more stable than 3 in solid state under air atmosphere. Complexes 1–4 were characterized by elemental analysis, NMR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (2, 3). The analytical results are in accord with their respective formulas. Because of the poor solubility of 1, 4 in common deuterated reagents, the expected information of 13C NMR was not achieved for both metal complexes. In the 1H NMR spectrum of 1–4, the benzylic hydrogen split as two separate doublets (3.27–4.58ppm, 4H) instead of one singlet (3.88ppm, 4H) in free linear trisphenol ligand, indicating that these hydrogens of methylene locate in a chiral environment which is similar to the analogous complexes [26]. The disappearance of the OH signal (6.64, 8.07ppm, 3H) of H 3 –L demonstrated that three oxygen atoms of the ligand have participated in the coordination to metal ions. The 1H NMR spectrums of 1–4 are quite similar suggesting that they adopted the same coordination mode. Single crystals of complex 2 suitable for X-ray structural determinations were obtained from slow cooling of a warm THF solution. The ORTEP drawing of 2 is displayed in Fig. 1 , along with selected bond lengths and angles. Both Zn1 and Zn2 are tetra-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from phenoxide groups with a distorted tetrahedral geometry around metal center. The average ZnO (Ar) bond length of 1.961(4)Å is comparable to the corresponding bond length of 1.941(3)Å in [(TBBP)2Zn][(Li)2(THF)4] [14]. Li+ ion is tetra-coordinated by two THF, two oxygen atoms of phenoxide with the average LiO (Ar) bond length of 1.964(11) Å and LiO (THF) bond length of 1.981(11) Å. In the structure of 2, the Li1–Zn1–Zn2 and Li2–Zn2–Zn1 angles of 178.5° and 179.1° indicate a collinear feature for these four metal atoms Li1, Li2, Zn1, and Zn2. Crystals of complex 3 can be obtained by cooling a warm saturated THF solution. As depicted in Fig. 2 , the structure of 3 is similar to complex 2, and the angles of 180° for Li1–Mg1–Mg1(A) and Li1(A)–Mg1(A)–Mg1 indicate that the metal atoms of Mg1, Mg1(A), Li1 and Li1(A) lie in a perfect line. The average MgO (Ar) bond length (1.954 (16) Å) in 3 is notably within a typical range published for MgO bonds [6,14]. Each lithium atom of 3 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of THF and phenoxide with a distorted tetrahedral geometry, which is similar to complex 2. 3.2 Ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of l-lactide The ROP of l-lactide (l-LA) catalyzed by complexes 1–3 was systematically conducted in both the absence and the presence of benzyl alcohol (BnOH) as a co-initiator with different monomer/initiator ratios at 110°C in toluene, and complex 4 was not tested due to its low solubility. Representative results of the polymerizations of l-LA under varied conditions are depicted in Table 1. The catalytic experimental results showed that complexes 1–3 are active for catalytic ROP of l-lactide, and about 90% conversion can be achieved within 36h with the ratio range from 100:1 to 250:1 for [lactide]/[complex]. Polymerization reactions catalyzed by 1 and 2 are under-control which can be proved by the linear relationship between molecular weights and the actual ratios of [LA]0/[complex]0, along with relatively low PDI values ranging from 1.47 to 1.55 (Table 1, entries 1–8, Figs. 3 and 4 ). Furthermore, epimerization of the chiral centers in PLA did not occur as observed by the homonuclear decoupled 1H NMR studies in the methine region [27]. Experiments were also conducted in the presence of an excess of benzyl alcohol as chain transfer agent. Representative results are shown in Table 1 (entries 10 and 11). The PLAs obtained from catalystic system of 1 indicated a better correlation between the experimental and calculated M n values. In order to investigate the stability of these complexes for ROP of l-LA and compare with the robust complex [(TBBP)2Zn][(Na)2(THF)4] [14], the weighing of catalysts 1 and 2 and the catalytic reactions for ROP were performed under air atmosphere. Although the obtained molecular weights are not well controlled, high monomer conversions can be achieved which demonstrated that both of the two metal complexes are active for ROP of l-LA under air atmosphere (entries 1–4, Table 2 ). In contrast with 1 and 2, polymerizations of l-LA catalyzed by the reported complex [(TBBP)2Zn][(Na)2(THF)4] suggest a “living” character under air atmosphere. In order to understand the different catalytic behaviors between them, 1H NMR titration of complex 2 in CDCl3 solution with water was operated (Fig. S7). After addition of water into the solution of complex 2 in CDCl3, the decrease of two separated doublets (3.27–4.58ppm) and the appearance of multiplets at 6.79–7.18 indicate that 2 has partially hydrolyzed to a mixture of some new metal complexes including lithium phenoxide. Because the activities of these mixed metal complexes as initiators are different and cannot compensate the decomposed complex 2 equally, the polymerization is not under-control under an air atmosphere due to the partial hydrolysis of complex 2 which is not similar to [(TBBP)2Zn][(Na)2(THF)4]. It is worth noting that addition of one equivalent of water to the catalytic system did not reduce the activities of complexes 1 and 2 for the polymerization of l-LA, which is different from the reported zirconium alkoxide [11] and hetero-bimetallic Fe(II) alkoxide/aryloxides initiators [13]. 3.3 Coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with cyclohexene oxide Compounds 1 and 2 were tested at 20bar pressure for the coupling reactions of carbon dioxide and cyclohexene oxide (CHO) with 0.1mol% catalyst and 1.0mol% n-Bu4NX (X =Cl, Br) as co-catalyst at 80°C, and cyclohexene carbonate (CHC) was produced with TONs ranging from 560 to 720 and TOFs from 34.8 to 43.9h−1 (Table 3 , entries 1–4). Experimental results showed that either in the presence of n-Bu4NCl or n-Bu4NBr, complex 2 is more active than 1. Using n-Bu4NBr as co-catalyst, higher conversions of 70 and 72% were obtained in the coupling reaction catalyzed by 1 and 2, respectively (entries 1, 3). This result is probably because the Br anion can accommodate better leaving group ability for cyclization and nucleophilicity for ring-opening during cycloaddition of CO2 with CHO [18b]. Increasing the pressure to 30bar, higher conversions can be achieved than that at 20bar (entries 5, 6). In the absence of complexes 1 and 2, the conversion of CHO was quite low (CHO conversion=38%, entry 7). It should be noted that the CHC catalyzed by 1 and 2 gives almost one isomer (cis-CHC>99%) evidenced by the 1H NMR spectrum [23]. 4 Conclusions Four novel heterobimetallic complexes 1–4 supported by a bulky trisphenol ligand have been synthesized and well characterized. The molecular structures of complexes 2 and 3 were further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques, and four metal atoms in each complex show a collinear feature. Complexes 1–3 exhibited remarkable activities for ring-opening polymerization of l-lactide, controllable ROP of l-LA has been displayed for catalysts 1 and 2; both two complexes also could catalyze ROP of l-LA with high conversion even under an air atmosphere. The coupling of carbon dioxide with cyclohexene oxide catalyzed by 1 and 2 in the presence of n-Bu4NX (X =Cl, Br) was also investigated under mild conditions, and the experimental results showed that the catalytic activity of 2 is higher than 1. coredata.dc:description: A series of heterobimetallic complexes supported by a bulky trisphenol ligand were synthesized and characterized. Treatment of 2,6-bis(3,5-bis-t-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)-4-t-butyl phenol with 1 equivalent sodium/ n BuLi and 1 equiv. Zn(Et)2 in THF solution afforded complex 1 or 2; metal complexes 3 and 4 were obtained in quantitative yields by alternating Zn(Et)2 to Mg( n Bu)2. The X-ray structures of 2 and 3 indicated that four metal atoms in the complexes are nearly collinear. Catalysis employing complexes 1–3 for l-lactide (l-LA) was systematically studied, and experimental results showed that 1 and 2 can catalyze the ring-opening polymerization of l-LA in a controlled fashion; what is more, both of these two complexes could catalyze l-LA with high conversion even in an air atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 also can effectively catalyze the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide with cyclohexene oxide using n-Bu4NBr/n-Bu4NCl as co-catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Zinc/magnesium–sodium/lithium heterobimetallic triphenolates: Synthesis, characterization, and application as catalysts in the ring-opening polymerization of l-lactide and CO2/epoxide coupling
